column1: Common rotator cuff problems include: - Tendinitis, which is irritation of the tendons and inflammation of the bursa (a normally smooth layer) lining these tendons - A tear, which occurs when one of the tendons is torn from overuse or injury
Medicines, such as ibuprofen or naproxen, may help reduce swelling and pain.
Moist heat, such as a hot bath, shower, or a heat pack, can help when you feel pain in your shoulder.
An ice pack applied to the shoulder 20 minutes at a time, 3 to 4 times a day, may also help when you are in pain.
Your positions and posture during the day and night can also help relieve some of your shoulder pain: - When you sleep, lie either on the side that is not in pain or on your back.
These are exercises the therapist will do with your arm.
They help get the full movement back in your shoulder.

Also, when examined by your doctor or physical therapist, you should have: - Full strength in the muscles around your shoulder joint - Good range of motion of your shoulder blade and upper spine - No pain during certain physical exam tests that are meant to provoke pain in someone who has rotator cuff problems - No abnormal movement of your shoulder joint and shoulder blade Returning to sports and other activity should be gradual.
